snippet: When George E. Brown Jr., a 79-year-old Democrat representing California's 42nd Congressional District,  died last July, Republicans figured they finally had a good shot at capturing the seat that Mr. Brown had held for 27 years. Though Mr. Brown ...
lead_paragraph: When George E. Brown Jr., a 79-year-old Democrat representing California's 42nd Congressional District, died last July, Republicans figured they finally had a good shot at capturing the seat that Mr. Brown had held for 27 years. Though Mr. Brown had won 14 straight elections, Republican candidates had been steadily nibbling away at his winning margins as the district, centered on San Bernardino, just east of Los Angeles, grew more and more conservative and Mr. Brown remained steadfastly, unabashedly liberal.
abstract: Republican hopes of electing conservative Elia Pirozzi to serve out term of late California Congressman George E Brown Jr, an unabashed liberal, fade as Democrats nominate more centrist politician, state Sen Joe Baca; photo (Political Briefing) (S)

headline.main: For G.O.P., Sure Bet Turns Very Doubtful
